newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft's ActiveX has security flaw, Sun says.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft's ActiveX has security flaw, Sun says.

text.p: Sun Microsystems Inc on Thursday demonstrated what it said was a security loophole in Microsoft Corp's ActiveX technology, which it said could enable a malicious hacker to break into a computer user's private financial files.

Sun showed how when a specially written program containing ActiveX was downloaded by a remote user, the program then took over the user's computer and rifled its files for personal financial information.
The demonstration brought to light the danger of downloading software over the Internet, Sun said, saying its own Java software, a rival to ActiveX, was much more secure for users.
The demonstration was made during a keynote speech by Sun CEO Scott McNealy at the company's JavaOne conference.
"This raises the bar of security," Miko Matsumura, Sun's official "evangelist" for Java, said during the demonstration.

ActiveX is a powerful system of controls developed by Microsoft, which among other capabilities can make legitimate changes in a user's computer when the user downloads software from a Web site. The technology is a rival to Sun's Java initiative.

Sun executives said they see security as a major issue differentiating Java, which has been designed to enable programs to run in a protective "sandbox," and ActiveX, for which security has recently become a looming issue.
"We have a factor of 100 better security," Eric Schmidt, the Sun chief technology officer who is due to become chief executive of Novell Inc. next week, said in a recent interview.
"The only way we know of to provide this level of security is to run the program in its own little sandbox, which is what Java does," he said.
The program used in the demonstration was written by Fred Mclain, who said he did it to show the dangers of the powerful ActiveX software.

The ability to use ActiveX to infiltrate a computer in this way has been known for some time, but analysts said the Sun demonstration brought to light the danger of downloading software over the Internet.
Mclain, who develops programs for both ActiveX and for Java, said he would write similar programs on Java if future versions contain such security flaws.

"If you can do the same thing in Java, I'll do it," he said, adding it took him just a couple of days to write the intrusive ActiveX programs, but he estimates fixing the problem would take more than two man-years of work.
"This is an architectural security problem," he said.

Cornelius Willis, Microsoft's director of marketing for Internet platforms, said Microsoft has built in a certification -- similar to one to be adapted by Java -- to ensure Web users can track a software maker's origins.
Mclain's demonstration used a certificate, which he later said had been revoked. Willis said Microsoft is building in a feature to check for revoked certificates.
